intro: Acaena buchananii f. erubescens, commonly known as the red-fruited burrplant, is a flowering plant native to New Zealand. It belongs to the family Rosaceae and is characterized by its spiny, woody stems and small, clustered flowers. The plant produces bright red, berry-like fruits that are an important food source for native birds. Its leaves are alternate, simple, and often have a hairy texture. This shrub is well adapted to coastal and dry environments, thriving in well-drained soils.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acaena buchananii f. erubescens is primarily native to New Zealand. It is found in the South Island, particularly in the Canterbury and Otago regions. This plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky areas. It is adapted to the temperate climate of these regions. The subspecies is known for its distinctive red-tipped bracts and is part of the rose family.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena buchananii f. erubescens was mainly introduced to New Zealand. However, it has since become naturalized and is now considered a potential weed in some regions. The plant thrives in a variety of soil types and is tolerant of both full sun and partial shade.
